Campaign For Hospital
Funds To Open April 23
Between 300 and 400 of Baltimore's leading citizens are expected to attend the dinner on April
23 that will launch the campaign
for a $200,000 sustaining fund for
the charity work of the Johns
Hopkins Hospital over the next
two years. The dinner will be held
at the Hotel Belvedere.
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, presidentelect of the Johns Hopkins University, and United States Senator
Millard E. Tydings will be the
guest speakers, it was announced
by W. Frank Roberts, chairman
of the campaign.

Levin Attends I.N.A.
Confab At Ursinus
Hyman M. Levin, newly-elected assistant to the Grand Council of Pi
Delta Epsilon, national honorary journalism fraternity, attended the InterAssociation
Newspaper
collegiate
convention at Ursinus College last
Friday and Saturday, where he discussed the possibilities of organizing
new chapters of the national fraternity with delegates representing Ursinus, Haverford College, University
of Delaware, Drexel Institute, Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, and several
other institutions.
The first Pi Delt Bulletin, containing chapter and Grand Council news,
to be edited by Levin, will appear on
April 25, it was revealed today. The
Bulletin is being edited by the former
NEWS-LETTER editor in the capacity
of assistant to the Grand Editor of
the national fraternity.
It was announced today that Stanley E. Blumberg, who was a member
Of the I. N. A. elections committee,
was unable to attend the convention
at Ursinus, where he was to have
read a paper on "The College Newspaper As An Experiment In Journallam."

Corps, will speak on "Munitions and

lectures in some of the northern colleges and universities. On one occasion he held a series of debates with
Senator Bertram Nye, Republican
from North Dakota, on several questions pertinent to munition control
by the government.
Shaffer To Give Trophies
Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, director of
Intramural athletics, will present the
various trophies to winning fraternity
and departmental teams in the volleyball and basketball leagues. Delta
Upsilon were the winners of the basketball crown among the frats, while
Sigma Phi Epsilon copped honors in
the volleyball race in the same class.
McClean said today the speakers
have been secured for the remaining
assemblies. The honorary fraternities
will also hold their public inductions
during the remainder of the year.

Dr. A. C. Lovejoy, professor of philosophy, has called attention to an error in an article printed in last Friday's NEWS-LETTER on the hearing on
Teachers' Oath Bill before Governor
Nice. He said at that time, in answer
to the question of Governor Nice
whether he would support a bill providing penalties for the teaching of

"The classroom is not the place for

Socialist, Communist, or any other;

would support such a bill. The paper
is sorry for this error.

view with the following words, in
making this correction:
"As for the right of the individual,
teacher or any other citizen, to advocate and agitate for any change in
our institutions which he may believe
desirable; I recognize no limit to this
right, provided such agitation does
not take the form of physical violence.

manner provided in the Constitution
itself; and the first article of the Bill
of Rights in the Maryland Constitution asserts the inalienable right of
the people to alter, reform or abolish
their form of Government in such
manner as they may deem expedient.

What Is Your Solution?
The crux of the matter seems to
lie in the fact that many of these
students have never really tried to
produce genuine answers to some of
these social problems. Criticism is
very good, but it should be given and
received in the proper spirit: and that
means constructively. There is usually little use in criticism which is
totally destructive. The question that
must be continually addressed to the
critic is "What is your solution?"
Failing to answer this question usually shows the critic to be a rather
shallow thinker. Answering it usually helps to lead to a solution, since
the answer is likewise open to criticism; and mutual criticism forces a
comparison of values, which should
bring at least a tentative answer.
It is to this purpose of searching
for worthwhile conclusions that the

Dr. A. C. Lovejoy, professor of philosophy, has called attention to an error in an article printed in last Friday's NEWS-LETTER on the hearing on
Teachers' Oath Bill before Governor
Nice. He said at that time, in answer
to the question of Governor Nice
whether he would support a bill providing penalties for the teaching of
propaganda, that he believed that
"The classroom is not the place for
propaganda, Republican, Democratic,
Socialist, Communist, or any other;
but it is up to the separate institutions to decide this matter."
The NEWS-LETTER originally stated
that he had said that he thought he
would support such a bill. The paper
is sorry for this error.
Dr. Lovejoy further clarified his
view with the following words, in
making this correction:
"As for the right of the individual,
teacher or any other citizen, to advocate and agitate for any change in
our institutions which he may believe
desirable; I recognize no limit to this
right, provided such agitation does
not take the form of physical violence.
A fundamental principle of the Constitution is that it may be changed
at any time and to any extent in the
manner provided in the Constitution
itself; and the first article of the Bill
of Rights in the Maryland Constitution asserts the inalienable right of
the people to alter, reform or abolish
their form of Government in such
manner as they may deem expedient.

A man who visited a Chesterfield
factory recently, said:"Now that I have
seen Chesterfields made, I understand
better than ever why people say Chesterfields are milder and have a better taste."
If you too could visit our factories you could
see the clean, airy surroundings; the employees
in their spotless uniforms, and the modern cigarette making machinery.
You could notice how carefully each Chesterfield cigarette is inspected and gee also how
Chesterfields are practically untouched by human
hands.
Whenever you happen to be in Richmond,Va.,
Durham, N. C., or San Francisco, California, we
invite you to stop at the Liggett & Myers plants
and see how Chesterfields are made.

One of the departments that will
get less money will be the Department of Physical Training and Athletics, which has already left itself
open to the charge of overeconomizing. What will be the effect next year
when a football uniform will have to
be treated like a dress suit?
Those men who stood on the fringe
of Friday's meeting have to realize
that nothing is too sacred to be affected by finance—not even athletics.
They must also realize that the smell
in Annapolis where the State Legislature sits does not come from the
fish market.
